In 1905, Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim eastern half. The two halves of Bengal were later re-merged in 1911 to form the large province of Bengal. From 1947 to 1971, both western and eastern parts of the new state of East Pakistan, i.e. the regions of modern Bangladesh and Assam, were Muslim majority, whereas the central parts of West Bengal remained Indian Hindu majority. East Pakistan underwent mass riots in 1952, 1964 and 1970; the country came under Bangladesh's control in 1971, and East Pakistan became Bangladesh in December. The state of West Bengal remained Indian Hindu majority under the government of India.

The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire, including that of the Han Chinese, Khitans, Jurchens, Koreans and Mongols. Unlike that of his predecessors, the system was more centralized and the bureaucracy far greater in size. As the empire had only recently been unified, local cultures had been preserved or replaced by that of the Mongol invader. This meant that the bureaucratic system implemented was that of Central Asia and the Khitans, with little attempt made to adjust it. There were two levels on the imperial civil service staff, the official civil service was divided, each based on local cultures, and the imperial civil service was centralized and made up of bureaucrats from Central Asia and the Khitans. The system was further reinforced by the addition of a third level of local office, although these offices were more subordinate in rank to the prefectural offices of prefects and magistrates. Each office consisted of an inspector, a magistrate, a secretary and twelve deputies

Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements, particularly along the east coast of Ireland, the west coast of modern Scotland, and the Hebrides. The Vikings are believed to have also settled in the Hebrides, which has been confirmed by archaeological findings.

The Norse who settled in Ireland and Scotland faced a hostile environment as they competed with the native Irish, Picts, and Scots for control of territories and resources. This led to frequent conflicts and struggles for power. The Norse also brought their culture and traditions to these regions, which had a lasting impact on the societies and languages.

The Scottish Vikings continued north, reaching the Firth of Forth and the area surrounding the present-day capital, Edinburgh in the latter half of the century. The northwestern portion of Rajasthan is generally sandy and dry. Most of this region are covered by the Thar Desert which extends into adjoining portions of neighboring India and Pakistan. Only a part of the Thar region is covered by the desert where the rain fall is so low that the land is covered by a layer of hard sandy dirt called loess (the loess desert). The rest of the region is covered by saline desert with shallow saline lakes. The northern part of the state is covered by the Bundelkhand uplands which are divided almost equally by the Narmada and Tapti rivers. The western portion of the state consists of hilly uplands on the western boundary of North India. There are many reasons why we might set such exclusive boundaries. We might set them in order to avoid the loss of something meaningful, to be sure that we are respected, to be sure that others do not disrespect us, to be sure no one tries to steal something from us, to be sure someone will not take our love away from us, to make money, or to feel that we are superior and others are inferior.

Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute began as a child development laboratory in a small barn owned by J.J. Macfarlane on property next to the Berkeley High School campus. In 1938, the Institute moved to its current location, in the Berkeley School of Education building. The Institute expanded considerably throughout the Second World War era. In 1944 the Institute was renamed the Institute of Human Biology. In the 1990s, the Institute came under the leadership of a partnership between UC Berkeley, the University of Pennsylvania, and the Institute for Research on Poverty of the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Today it is jointly known as the Center on the Developing Child.

The authors argue that different regions in the same continent or part of the same continent were once unified and later divided by the separation of a supercontinent, so that what was once connected is now disconnected. There are many forms of spiritual or religious teachers in Christianity, across all three major traditions - (Roman) Catholic, (Eastern) Orthodox Catholic, and (Protestant or Evangelical). Spiritual or religious teachers are people who teach about God and Jesus, and help people to understand their faith better. They are also called pastors, priests or bishops. Spiritual or religious teachers are important because they guide people in their spiritual life and help them stay connected to God.

Some examples of spiritual or religious teachers in Christianity are: Pope, Bishops, Priests, and Pastor. Each of these positions have different roles and responsibilities, but they all play a crucial role in teaching about God and Jesus to their followers. For example, a Pope is the head of the Catholic Church and is considered the successor of Saint Peter, who was one of Jesus' twelve disciples. Bishops and Priests are leaders of a specific diocese or church, and they are responsible for overseeing the spiritual life of their followers

Statistically speaking, cable-borne elevators are extremely safe. Their safety record is unsurpassed by any other vehicle system. In 1998, it was estimated that more than 30 million passengers travel safely every day in the approximately 1.4 million elevators found at colleges and universities in the USA. In addition, more than 400,000 miles of cable are operated every day at airports, hospitals and other large buildings. These elevators have been studied countless times by industry and government organizations looking to understand what causes elevator accidents.
It is well proven that the most frequent cause of elevator accidents and failures is improper installation, maintenance and repair. According to a U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission study of elevator accidents involving deaths and injuries from 1990 to 1998, nearly 85% of the accidents were caused by user error. The Armenian Genocide caused widespread emigration that led to the settlement of Armenians in various countries in the world. Armenians kept to their traditions and certain aspects of Armenian culture; however, they integrated with the societies in which they settled and adopted some new aspects of the dominant culture.

The first large scale Armenian migration abroad took place during the early 1820s as a flight from the 1821 genocide. Armenians were also forced to migrate during the 1915 Armenian genocide, after which several thousand Armenians settled in the Ottoman empire, primarily in Lebanon and Syria. Throughout the period of the Armenian genocide, tens of thousands of Armenians also migrated to what was then called the Russian Empire. Some of them went to Egypt, Egypt, and Palestine. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a banana from the side of her head in the course of the hand gesture. That's why we can talk of asymmetric causality in a biological context.

"Biophysical asymmetry" is an abstraction that concerns only the cause-effect relations which are directly connected to the internal state of an organism or one of its parts. This would allow us to explain the spontaneous or directed movements of an arm without postulating a teleology of the movement, a teleology in this context meaning that the hand is moving itself. If the teleology did apply, it would imply a purpose of the movement which cannot be given by the material conditions present. Biophysical asymmetry excludes teleology as much as it excludes materialism.

In other words, biophysical asymmetry rejects teleological explanations and yet it is not some kind of materialistic explanation

By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike a decisive blow against the enemy's mainland possessions. Instead of launching a costly and risky move onto the continent, Napoleon decided to send a small expedition from his position in the western Mediterranean, using the sea to circumvent the Continental powers and sail directly towards the Isle of Cyprus. This move was driven by a sense of national pride and loyalty to his homeland, a passion that Napoleon shared with his fellow Romans.

The expeditionary force comprised of over 2,000 men, divided into four divisions, led by various generals including Bonaparte, Moncey, and Junot. Their arrival on the island on August 19th was met with celebrations and grand festivities, as the Roman people rejoiced at the prospect of liberation from foreign rule. However, the real challenge lay ahead - taking control of the strategically important city of Chypre.

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species evolved different behaviors with different levels of risk from predation. For instance, some mammals are nocturnal and avoid predators which is an especially risky strategy given that many predators have also adapted to nocturnal hunting. In contrast, some mammals live in communities which may protect each individual, while some species are solitary hunters which gives them a low risk of predation. The energetic and/or risk costs of different strategies could have influenced differences in morphological variation (e.g. differences in head size) that are used as a proxy for sociality.

In 2009, IGN named the Xbox 360 the sixth-greatest video game console of all time, out of a field of 25. In the past, teachers have been paid relatively low salaries. However, average teacher salaries have improved rapidly in recent years. US teachers are generally paid on the lower end of comparable professions across the world, with the exception of Germany. In Germany, an average teacher is paid more than $90,000 annually, while an average public school teacher in the United States is paid $58,000 a year.

The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century, with compositions by Josquin des Prez, Diether de Bruges, Philippe Verdelot, and Philippe Verdelot. A cappella polyphony quickly spread across Europe through the efforts of French and English musicians such as Alexander Dunbar, Johannes Puer. It became popular in Russia in the late 16th century and has since spread to other parts of the world such as India and the Western United States.

The polyphony of Christian a cappella music is known for its use of multiple voices singing different parts of the melody. It is notated using different symbols and marks, such as clefs, staves, and bar lines. The music is usually written for one or more choirs, although singers without instruments have also been known to participate. The city of Jerusalem is of special importance to Jews, Muslims and Christians as it is the home of sites that are pivotal to their religious beliefs, such as the Western Wall of Judaism, Haram Al-Sharif of Islam and the Dome of the Rock of Christianity. In the course of the Battle of Jerusalem in 1099 AD, Jerusalem became the capital of the Kingdom of Jerusalem, which lasted until 1187 AD. Jews, Muslims and Christians coexisted for several hundred years in the city. However, during the Crusades of the 12th to 15th century, Jerusalem became the capital of the Holy Roman and Crusader Empires, the city being under foreign rule for approximately 500 years.

In the late 19th century, modern technology led to the development of industry in Jerusalem and paved its way to becoming the capital of British Mandate of Palestine in 1922. The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons. On the day of the event, members of the sovereign's household are transported on carriages to the Palace of Westminster. The sovereign is accompanied by members of the Royal Household and is addressed by members of the Senate, followed by the speaker of the House of Lords, usually the Duke of Edinburgh, and the Lord Chancellor. The sovereign then meets with the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, followed by the Lords Present at the Crown, and finally presents their instrument of government, the "Great Seal", to the queen's personal secretary, the Keeper of the Privy Purse. This marks the official beginning of the royal administration for that year. To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is, or at least it should be, the case in all systems of this kind. Where this is not feasible, a warning device could be fitted to the receiving tank, to indicate when it is receiving 'foreign matter'. This should ideally give a clear indication in the form of flashing lights that something other than the required water supply is being taken on board. The water level of the tank would indicate that an alarm was not triggered and would indicate a problem to be investigated.

In the case of the small single-section feed from a single water supply there are two solutions: a) fitting a two stage air separator to the line at about every 0.5 m (or more often), or b) using a double-tank arrangement as detailed in Chapter 8 and/or 7, section 2.3.

One classic example of egocentrism in adolescence is the "I look at you differently when you're not looking" type of thought. (This is sometimes referred to as "Mirror Imaging" or "Theory of Mind".)

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence. Adolescents learn to balance two very different roles: as a child with emotional and physical needs and as a child who has certain rights and responsibilities within the family. This process often involves struggles for control between parents and children. Adolescents are expected to become more mature, but at the same time parents wish to maintain closeness to their children. In such transitional times there is much confusion, even when there is love and affection. Parents and adolescents can find themselves in constant arguments, and the adolescent is always on guard.
Parents are expected to support their children and are not permitted to make too many demands.
In adolescence roles and responsibilities are clearly established and a lot of pressure is placed on the adolescent to become independent. Parental support is still expected and the parents do not interfere much with everyday decisions.

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A pure culture of the specific agent is selected from the microflora growing on the medium. It is the pure culture providing the important data for the identification of the disease-causing agent and for therapeutic, preventive, or other purposes. The term also refers to cultures on an intermediate or artificial host, where a pure culture is difficult or impossible to obtain. The culture may be incubated in a simple device, or maintained at various sites within a complex apparatus (e.g., centrifuges, flow hoods, and bioreactors). The culture may have special control and monitoring devices, such as a spectrophotometer or an electrochemical cell.

A predator's effect on its prey species is hard to see in the short-term. However, if observed over a longer period of time, it is possible to see how predators can have significant effects on the population and behaviour of their prey.
There are several key points which help explain what happens.
First, predtors usually select their prey from within a broad range of sizes. They thus affect the size of the largest animals that they tend to hunt.
A related effect is that the predators will tend to choose those individuals in a population that have traits that make them highly vulnerable and easily attacked.
This process, which is known as natural selection, has been demonstrated time and time again in the evolution of large mammals (for example, the wildebeest of the plains of Africa). There is often a strong relationship between the vulnerability of prey species to predation and the amount of prey killed.
In most cases, predation exerts strong pressure on the entire prey population

The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by the Longshan farmers. They were in contact with the Zhou civilisation during the Warring States period (c. 531 BC - 221 BC), when an alliance of various local rulers broke away from the Zhou state, creating the Former Yan with its capital at Long Yan. The area became a tributary state of the Former Yan, but soon disintegrated.

In the 3rd century BC, the Qin dynasty conquered the region and annexed it as part of Han China, named Jianye Commandery. From 221 BC to AD 23, this was the seat of the Han dynasty's most northerly administration. Later, Jianye Commandery was incorporated into the newly-founded Shaoxing Commandery, which covered most of modern Zhejiang.

Zhejiang was annexed to the Northern Song dynasty in 979 AD

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. The Notre Dame football team was the first of the modern powerhouse college programs, which rose to national prominence and dominance through the mid-20th century. The Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team has won 11 national championships and 21 conference championships. Notre Dame's first two national titles and all five since the 1970s have been earned while the Fighting Irish were coached by the current Fighting Irish coach Brian Kelly. At the college's annual homecoming game against Michigan State, a tradition began in 1919 in which the "Hail to Notre Dame" chorus sings of Ireland's victories. It has led to the popularity of the song "God Bless America" which many students and fans associate with Notre Dame.

The Fighting Irish men's basketball team rose to prominence in the 1930s and '40s, winning two national championships and one AAU national championship.

The Yale Report of 1828 was a dogmatic defense of the Latin and Greek curriculum against critics who wanted more courses in modern languages, mathematics, and science, as well as American history. Its authors, Edward Atkinson and Levi Woodbury, sought to demonstrate that the Latin and Greek curriculum at Yale predated America, while also linking the ancient university tradition to the founding of the United States.

The Report was written without the use of footnotes, as Atkinson and Woodbury did not see the need for them. The authors also insisted that any history courses follow their specific model of narrative and style.

Background
The idea for the report began when Woodbury and Atkinson were asked to write a historical textbook that would appeal to future alumni of the university. Their goal was to emphasize the classical studies that were foundational to American democracy. These texts were important for alumni to bring back to their respective states as they became governors.

The authors began researching the history of universities in the United States

The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were biased by the translator's own agenda.
The Origin of Species, Darwin's seminal book on evolution, was first published in April 1859. It argued against the prevalent belief that species remained unchanged over time because it was the offspring of species that acquired characteristics. Thus the offspring of certain plants with more developed seed pods, and more seeds in those pods, would have a greater chance of survival and thereby propagate their genes more widely.
The word 'origin' does not appear once in the book itself, yet there would have been many people eager to learn the 'origin' of the changes in Darwinian theory. This led to at least 10 books attempting to provide an account of the processes and forces that acted on animals prior to Darwin's time. The Free Movement of Workers Regulation articles 1 to 7 set out the main provisions on equal treatment of workers. First, articles 1 to 4 generally require that workers have equal treatment in the workplace with regard to matters such as wages, working conditions and employment rights. For instance, they must be provided with the same level of protection against dismissal, provided with the same working hours and paid the same for the same work (see Article 2: working conditions). These provisions ensure that employers are not able to set different contractual conditions for workers who perform the same tasks. They also promote equal opportunity in the workplace by not allowing unfair or discriminatory employment conditions.
The right to equal treatment is extended to cover a group of workers under different employer-employee contracts, known as ‘persons with the same or a similar status‘. In the China of the Yuan, or Mongol era, various important developments in the arts occurred or continued in their development, including the areas of painting, sculpture, calligraphy, lacquerware, porcelains, and textiles. The Yuan dynasty was influenced heavily by the Chinese imperial tradition, but sought to distance itself from Chinese cultural standards and established an independent Chinese culture under its administration. During the Yuan dynasty, artists who wrote their own style were called muping (; jingzhi) painters; those who imitated other artists, or followed the rules used by the imperial court, were called dashi muping (; jingshan zhenshan) painters. After the defeat of the Khwarezmian Empire in 1220, Genghis Khan gathered his forces in Persia and Armenia to return to the steppe.  He left his brother Börte's son and heir Chagatai of the Golden Horde as khan to rule over the territories of the former Khwarezmian Empire. Allusions to legal issues in To Kill a Mockingbird, particularly in scenes outside of the courtroom, has drawn the attention from legal scholars. Claudia B. Gold and Susan L. Harlow of University of Texas at Austin note that Harper Lee's depiction of Tom Robinson's trial is based on a 1954 case, Brown Brothers v. United States where Harper Lee's father's lawyer successfully argued for the acquittal of a client, after spending the first part of the argument describing the character as "the most virtuous man I have ever known."
"This use of a personal connection, as a part of a case, is very common. By making the character sympathetic, it could reduce jurors' feelings of hostility and bias," said gold and Harlow. "The judge was so impressed with the argument to the jury that he allowed lawyers to continue to use this example until the very end of the trial."

The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a beautiful landscape filled with fields and meadows. The middle part of the Saxon Switzerland is another picturesque region, characterized by its rocky hills and valleys. The Thuringian Forest takes over towards the south, surrounded by the Saale river and dotted with castles. As we move towards the southeast, we come across the Vogelsberg and the Harz Mountains. And finally, in the extreme southeast, we find the Lusatian Basin, which is the lowest land region in Thuringia.

But Thuringia is not just known for its beautiful landscapes. It also has a rich history and cultural heritage. The region was part of Roman rule until the Late Migration Period, and many of its villages and towns have preserved Romanesque architecture from that time. Although Ottoman madaris had a number of different branches of study, such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, they primarily served as intermediaries between the Ottoman court and the general population.

The Ottoman madaris were established by wealthy patrons who provided financial support for the education and maintenance of the madaris. These patrons were often rulers, religious authorities, and influential individuals within the Ottoman Empire. The madaris were led by a master or abbot, who was responsible for overseeing the education and spiritual guidance of the students.

One of the main activities of the Ottoman madaris was the preservation and dissemination of literature. The madaris served as centers for the production of books, ranging from religious texts, dictionaries, to literary works. The students were trained in the art of calligraphy and were responsible for copying and producing illuminated manuscripts. Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs before we ever take in a bite. This phase begins in the mouth and continues in the stomach and small intestines. In the cephalic phase, the salivary glands begin to secrete enzymes. This is triggered by the taste and smell of the food. Chewing also triggers the release of enzymes such as amylase (starch) and lipase (fats). Chewing also stimulates muscles in the intestines to empty to prepare for the movement of food and nutrients through the body. As an aid to salivation, the brain also releases a substance called gastrin, which activates the pancreas to release the enzyme pepsin, which breaks down proteins. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian, Montenegrin, and Serbian) have evolved separately. These languages are mutually intelligible, with Serbo-Croatian being commonly taught in neighboring countries and throughout the former Yugoslavia. Both Chakavian and Shtokavian are mutually intelligible, while Kajkavian is nearly unintelligible to Standard Serbo-Croatian speakers, but is spoken by Croatians. Montenegrin is not intelligible with Serbo-Croatian, although to some degree with Shtokavian. These three are the three official languages of Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Montenegro. Serbian is the official language of Serbia, as well as Kosovo. Bosnian and Albanian are unofficially recognised languages of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Albania, respectively

Banner Armies were organized along ethnic lines, namely Manchu and Mongol, but included non-Manchu bondservants registered under the household systems of the Banner Households.

In the 1760s the central-government sponsored a campaign to eliminate the banner system and assign all Manchu households to military units. This policy was unsuccessful, however; after the Manchu Bannermen defeated the Ming Dynasty rebels led by Li Zicheng, they were awarded hereditary land grants. The Jurchen-Manchu nobility, known collectively as the Eight Banners, ruled the Qing state from the late 16th century to the early 20th century, when they were overthrown in the 1911 Xinhai Revolution. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the only major mountain on the island being Devil's Peak), with few productive agricultural lands. The island's climate is temperate and dry, owing to its location in the subtropics.

Agriculture is limited to the cultivation of peanuts and bananas; much of the island's cultivated land is covered with pine plantations, principally a species known locally as "bay trees", of the genus Pinus, with many natural groves of indigenous pines also present.

Settlements

Jacksonville has suffered less damage from hurricanes than most other east coast cities, although the threat does exist for a direct hit by a major hurricane. The majority of the damage done by these tropical storms is caused by storm surge and flooding. The city’s population center, located on a peninsula along the St. Johns River, is well-protected from ocean flooding by miles of natural barrier islands and a network of levees. However, the river still poses a risk during an especially high storm event. The St. Johns River flows into the Atlantic Ocean, and high water levels can cause the river to overflow its banks, leading to flooding in low-lying areas.

In the event of a hurricane, it is important to take precautions to protect yourself and your property. One common sense step is to secure loose objects around your home, as they can become dangerous projectiles in strong winds. Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian is spoken only in certain parts of Spain, including the Valencian Community. The Spanish language is the only official language of Spain.

In the Valencia region, however, the Valencian language is widely spoken along with Spanish by a vast 80% of the locals as their native first language and 15% are bilingual speakers. The Valencian language is the third most widely spoken language in Spain after Spanish and Catalan, which is the official language of Catalonia. Spain's constitution considers Catalan a "regionally established language", which according to the constitution, must be taught in schools in the Catalan regions and in some municipalities of the Valencian Community. Spanish and Catalan are the de facto working languages also of the national government.

Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. When a baptized member is accused of committing a serious sin—usually cases of sexual misconduct or charges of apostasy or heresy—the matter is brought to a court of elders. The elders meet in private; if the charge is determined beyond "reasonable doubt," the accused is excommunicated. Excommunication (which is the permanent separation from the church, with no possibility of returning to the church) must be voted on by a two-thirds majority of congregation elders. A single elder can never make excommunication. In addition, any member who hears of an excommunicated member in his or her area of the congregation is required to leave the congregation as well.
When a member of a Southern Baptist church is accused of committing a serious sin, the matter is brought to a court of elders.

In response to the early-to-mid-17th century "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1689) that the existence of minds (or mental states) pre-dated any form of causal relationship and the notion of the mind as a physical object capable of causal explanation. Locke considered that the most fundamental form of mental state is that of a simple predicate, the existence of which Locke maintained "is the necessary condition for all other mental states..." However, in his later works (such as An Essay Concerning Human Understanding and the Two Treatises of Government), Locke concluded that while the mere existence of a subject's mental state may be enough to justify the state that one observes in the state of the subject, there needs to be an external event (a physical body) in order to justify the state of the subject. The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea started to break apart. The breakup of Pangaea led to isolation and the growth of new, separate supercontinents, such as Gondwana, Laurasia and Laurussia. During the Jurassic, all three supercontinents eventually collided, forming a single supercontinent called Laurussia. The Jurassic marked the height of the Mesozoic Era.

Early Jurassic: 201.3 ± 0.2 - 174.0 Ma 
The Early Jurassic can be divided into three periods: Early, Middle and End.

Almost all ctenophores are predators – there are no vegetarians and only one genus that is partly parasitic. If food is plentiful, they can grow very quickly and sometimes increase their size by five or six orders of magnitude. In contrast to the animals with cnidocysts a ctenophore does not store venom.
If the temperature increases, the animal's body temperature matches it and the body is able to produce heat as required for optimal performance. Animals, on the other hand, have an internal body temperature of about 36.5 degrees Celsius, and only a few species have developed heat regulation.
In ctenophores, movement is achieved with hundreds or even thousands of little cilia, which are arranged in a crown-like structure.

The advances made in the Middle East in botany and chemistry led medicine in medieval Islam substantially to develop pharmacology. Muhammad ibn Zakarīya Rāzi, also known as Rhazes, wrote Materia Medica, in 961. It includes descriptions of diseases, their causes, prevention and also treatments. Rhazes' works were known all over Europe. Rhazes, one of the world's first pharmacologists, was also the first to write about ophthalmology, dermatology, the anatomy of the heart, and to discover the cure for malaria among his works, which has remained in use to this day. Also the first Persian book to systematically and methodically classify plants into families was the Canon, written in 1062. The first known chemical synthesis of morphine was reported by Persian chemist and physician Avicenna (980–1037) between 1025 and 1030.

Comprehensive schools have been accused of grade inflation after a study revealed that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability found themselves at the very bottom of their Year 12 class for the past three years.
On Thursday, the first senior secondary students to finish the transition to the Victorian education system since 2007 faced off with students from the previous year.
The tests, which examine students in mathematics at the top end of the school system, have become a popular measure of student achievement amid concerns over grade inflation.
Students are given two to three hours to complete the test, which include four sections. Each section is worth 45 marks, for a maximum total of 270 marks.
The results are then compared to the results of two or three years earlier to assess student improvement.
In the most recent testing, some 80 per cent of senior secondary Matriculants achieved an "advanced" level. But less than 45 per cent of them scored the equivalent of 10 points on the mathematics ATAR scale

In the north eastern part of Fresno, Woodward Park was founded by the late Ralph Woodward, a long-time Fresno resident. He bequeathed the park to the city after his death in 1984, along with other bequests including a library, a wildlife sanctuary, two tennis courts, an elementary school, and a park, naming all those things with a surname: Woodward. The neighborhood in which the park is situated was originally an all-white, very exclusive neighborhood known as Woodward Addition. The Woodward Addition was annexed to the city of Fresno in 1922. Woodward Park has had a community garden since the early 1990s. In 2006, there were approximately 40 residents of the community garden. The garden was later threatened with closure and was sold and reopened as the Woodward Center for Community and Gardens in 2012. Woodward Center for Community and Gardens is the successor of the Woodward Community Garden.
